abstract.t: This document updates to depreciate the Status DNS OpCode.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: The Status OpCode was given the value of 2 in . However, no RFC defines what it means or how it should be used. This document makes the Status OpCode obsolete.

section.title: Terminology
section.t: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "NOT RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in BCP 14 when, and only when, they appear in all capitals, as shown here.

section.title: Implementation Status
section.t: To the author's knowledge there is no implementation of the Status OpCode. A quick test shows inconsistent responses to a Status request with different DNS server implementations returning NotImp, Refused or giving no response at all.

section.title: Depreciating the Status OpCode
section.t: The Status OpCode MUST be marked OBSOLETE.
The correct response to the Status OpCode MUST be NotImp.

section.title: IANA Considerations
section.t: This documents updates the IANA registry "Domain Name System (DNS) Parameters OpCode registry" .

section.title: Acknowledgments
section.t: Thanks to Mark Andrews, Matt Pounsett, Roy Arends and all the people at IETF 104 that I asked if they knew of any usage of this OpCode. Also thanks to Shane Kerr for reminding me to write this document.
